Does this work for a Tony Mac Hackintosh ?? Please quick help

DO NOT DOWNLOAD
DO NOT DOWNLOAD
DO NOT DOWNLOAD
DO NOT DOWNLOAD

THIS IS NOT WORKING FOR A HACKINTOSH(THE TONY MAC METHOD). THIS IS JUST THE IMAGE OF BOOTCAMP NOT THE COMPLETE OS....
So all i need to do is mount the iso file and i can download right ? can it download on NTFS hard drive ?

IMPORTANT, PLEASE READ!

This is a disk image of a MacBook Pro system restore DVD. It will ONLY work on 2010/11 MacBook Pros. It WON'T work on PCs, virtual machines or other Mac systems.

Hackintoshers need a RETAIL version of Mac OS or try Googling "iATKOS".

This image can be burned to a DUAL-LAYER DVD using Nero (PC) or Disk Utility (Mac). Mac users can use Disk Utility to RESTORE the image to a USB flash drive which will boot quicker than a DVD (format the flash drive as GUID/HFS+ unjournaled).

Disregard any negative comments as this DVD image DOES work on those systems it was designed to work on.

Many thanks MILKYTECH, this is invaluable for MBP owners without restore media :)
pleeeaseee seeeeed! I'm getting this in one week...

Work perfect with my MBP Late 2011.
Don't forget to run the Software update to update it to 10.6.8.
Thanks I needed this is the November MacBook Pro that cam with Lion. I needed Rosetta badly and this worked perfectly!!!

Holy fuck!!! I have been trying to install Snow Leopard on a clients Macbook Pro for over 1 week now and finally this ISO made all the difference!!! I tried at least 10 different version of snow leopard before finally realizing that I had to install this specific version for this macbook pro early 2011. Since I only had a PC to work from I used Transmac to burn it onto the disk. I was originally trying to use a thumb drive to install but kept getting kernal panic errors... I also had no luck with the DMG version of this torrent, that one could not locate the drivers. This was my final option and I am glad it worked on a Dual Layer DVD. Again thanks so much for this upload!!!

This hasn't worked on any unibody MacBook Pro I tried it on. The uploader would be very nice to tell which exact hardware version used this image. 

I was told about a "universal" 10.6.8 or 10.6.7 that would go on mid-2011 MacBook Pros. 

Heck, I just can't get used to Lion's weird ergonomics.
I actually got it working under vmware with boot darwin.iso.
